We've completed one of the largest
renewable energy projects, in the National Trust.

5.text: This hydroelectricity generating site will be producing more electricity,

10.text: than all the properties we have here in Wales use for lighting.

15.text: I'm really proud that we've created a legacy,

17.text: for the next 100 years, in producing clean energy,

20.text: but the bit I'm most proud about,

23.text: is being able to do an awful lot of work,

27.text: One of our measures of success has been that you can't see we've done any work.

32.text: What we've actually built, in practical terms,

35.text: is we've got a mile of pipe, and that we had a helicopter up the mountain,

40.text: down in the valley bottom, we've got six tonnes of steel,

44.text: that goes round and round, that generates electricity,

47.text: and high up on the mountain, we built a small weir,

50.text: which is basically just a filter, a way of getting water into the pipe.

56.text: The technology's been really clever, and smart, and exciting, but it's actually been part of a team,

62.text: delivering a fantastic project, but in a stunning place.

65.text: One of the big players, in building in such an environment,

68.text: has been the weather, and we've had a stunning summer,

71.text: which has helped us a lot, and now that it's started to rain again,

76.text: it's almost like it's the perfect ingredients for a hydro.

79.text:
This farm, and so many other hill farms in
Wales,

83.text: is facing an uncertain time, in the sense that farm support is declining,

87.text: and, renewable energy, effectively, is a new cash crop for us.

92.text: We're limited in what we can do,

94.text: and renewables really have given us a secure future.

99.text: But the National Trust isn't a power generating company,

107.text: and by actually generating our own power,

110.text: not only do we help with the whole sustainability agenda,

114.text: but we'll also generate income, which will further our conservation work.
